node.category: Q0: {What is the way things are?}
Q1.1: {What does Susie do?}

node.surface: Susie lifts the lid of the abandoned teapot
and swirls the water.

node.category: Q1.2: {What happens as Susie swirls the water inside the abandoned teapot?}

node.surface: The teabag sloshes against the sides.

node.category: Q1.2.1: {How is the tea in the abandoned teapot?}

node.surface: The tea is cold and bitter,

node.category: Q1.2.2: {What does Susie think about the fact that the tea is cold a bitter?}

node.surface: but Susie doesn't mind

node.category: Q1.2.3.1: {Why doesn't Susie mind the fact that the tea is cold and bitter?}

node.surface: because her landlady, Mrs Simpson, normally reuses tea bags.
Usually, by the time Susie gets home, the tea mostly tastes of chlorine.

node.category: Q1.2.1: {What does Susie do next?}

node.surface: As she checks Mrs Simpson's calendar,
Susie rubs the place where the elastic cap from work scrunched all day.

node.category: Q1.2.2: {What does Susie see marked in the calendar?}

node.surface: A play.

node.category: Q1.2.3: {What about the place where the elastic cap from work scrunched all day?}

node.surface: The skin feels puckered and soft, like white and wrinkly fingertips in the bath.

node.category: Q1.2.4.1: {What does the state of her skin remind Susie of?}

node.surface: Her mother used to read beside the clawfoot bathtub her father imported from England.
Susie—who wasn't a Susie at all then—would tuck her chin over the edge of the tub and listen.
The water would go cold.
Her skin would loose and crinkle.

node.category: Q1.2.4.2: {Does Mrs Simpson make an exception of reusing teabags?}

node.surface: Mrs Simpson only makes fresh tea for Mr Johnson next door.

node.category: Q1.2.4.3: {How is Mr. Johnsons tea also different from the others?}

node.surface: One cup still contains a moss-smoke slick of whiskey.

node.category: Q1.3.1: {What does Susie do now - with the cup containing some whiskey?}

node.surface: Susie wipes the rim of the cup with her sleeve
then pours herself some tea.

node.category: Q1.3.2: {What about the remaining whiskey in the cup?}

node.surface: The whiskey is too dilute to be warm

node.category: Q1.3.3: {Does Susie mind that the whiskey is too dilute to be warm?}

node.surface: but it's nice to know it's there.

node.category: Q1.4.1: {What does Susie see while drinking the the tea with some whiskey in it?}

node.surface: In the kitchen window, she sees the red elastic mark below her hairline.

node.category: Q1.4.2: {What is her reaction to seeing the mark below her hairline?}

node.surface: She suppresses a sigh

node.category: Q1.4.3: {How does Susie feel as she suppresses that sigh?}

node.surface: and the air sits heavy in her chest.

node.category: Q1.4.4: {How does Susie deal with the feeling of heavy air in her chest?}

node.surface: Susie has a knack for ignoring discomfit.

node.category: Q1.4.5: {How does that ability to ignore discomfit help her in her daily life?}

node.surface: It comes in handy at the factory.

node.category: Q1.4.6: {Is there an example of how this comes handy at the factory?}

node.surface: She felt an itch that morning
but didn't scratch it until after her shift had ended.

node.category: Q2.1: {What about Susies work?}

node.surface: She scrubs her face pink before each shift.

node.category: Q2.2.1: {Why does Susie scrub her face like that before each shift?}

node.surface: A single flake of dead skin can ruin a microchip.

node.category: Q2.2.2: {How can her workplace be described further?}

node.surface: But the factory is also vacuum-dry

node.category: Q1.2.3: {How the vacuum-dry factory affect Susie?}

node.surface: and she has to moisturise often.

node.category: Q1.2.4: {How does she keep her face moisturized, if she has to moisturize often?}

node.surface: She can only afford sunflower oil.

node.category: Q1.2.5: {What about sunflower oil?}

node.surface: For the whole day, she breathes the bitter staleness of cooking oil trapped behind the mask.

node.category: Q2.2.6: {What other problems, except breathing in the cooking oil trapped behind the mask, does Susie face at work?}

node.surface: Her tongue is always wool.

node.category: Q2.2.7: {Why does her tongue feel wool?}

node.surface: In the dust-free factory, her mouth fills with the rat-grey feel of it.

node.category: Q1.1.3.3: {Where is Mrs Simpson?}

node.surface: Even if it's a matinee, Mr Johnson will insist on dinner.

node.category: Q1.1.3.4: {What about the dinner?}

node.surface: Mrs Simpson will pay.

node.category: Q1.5: {What does Susie do next?}

node.surface: She swallows the tea.

node.category: Q1.6.1: {What does Susie do after drinking the tea?}

node.surface: Susie climbs the stairs to Mrs Simpson's room

node.category: Q1.6.2: {What does Susie do up the stairs?}

node.surface: and tries the door.

node.category: Q1.6.3: {What about the door?}

node.surface: It's locked.

node.category: Q1.6.4.1: {Where does Susie go next?}

node.surface: In the shower room Susie shares with the taxi driver she's never met, she finds hairpins strewn around the sink.

node.category: Q1.6.4.2: {Who owns these hairpins?}

node.surface: She's not sure if they are Mrs Simpson's or if the taxi driver has female guests.

node.category: Q1.6.4.3: {Is it likely that the taxi driver has female guests over?}

node.surface: Guests aren't allowed, of course,
but Susie doesn't know enough about the taxi driver to know if he's the type to flaunt the rules.

node.category: Q1.6.5.1: {What does Susie do after she acquired the hairpins?}

node.surface: She picks the lock to Mrs Simpson's room.

node.category: Q1.6.5.2: {Does Susie know Mrs Simpsons room?}

node.surface: Susie's in there every week to clean,

node.category: Q1.6.5.3: {Is she allowed to go into Mrs Simpsons rooms alone?}

node.surface: but only under Mrs Simpson's watchful eye.

node.category: Q3.1: {What about Mrs Simpson?}

node.surface: Mrs Simpson doesn't trust people.

node.category: Q3.2: {Does she distrust some people more than others?}

node.surface: She especially doesn't trust immigrants.

node.category: Q3.3.1: {What does Susie think about the fact that Mrs Simpson doesn't trust immigrants?}

node.surface: Susie wonders why Mrs Simpson decided to live with two

node.category: Q3.3.2: {Who is the other immigrant in Mrs Simpsons household?}

node.surface: (Susie knows the taxi driver is an immigrant

node.category: Q3.3.3: {How does Susie know that the taxi driver is an immigrant?}

node.surface: because Mrs Simpson often says: ‘Oh, I suppose you two are exceptions to the rule',

node.category: Q3.3.4: {What is the rule Mrs Simpson is talking about and to which the taxi driver and Susie are the exception?}

node.surface: the rule being that immigrants impact everything in Mrs Simpson's life and society and the country negatively).

node.category: Q3.3.5: {How did Mrs. Simpson come up with this rule?}

node.surface: Susie suspects it has something to do with the small rooms and the black mould that spots the wallpaper.

node.category: Q3.4.1: {What else did Mrs. Simpson talk about when it came to living in her apartment?}

node.surface: Also, in her interview for the room, Mrs Simpson clearly stated she was looking for someone who works during the day.

node.category: Q3.4.2: {During the interview for the room - why did Mrs Simpson want someone who works during the day?}

node.surface: She already had someone who worked during the night.

node.category: Q3.4.3: {Why did she want a renter who was there at night?}

node.surface: If she fell and broke her hip at midnight, she needed to know she could rely on the person to be in.

node.category: Q3.4.3: {What does Susie think about the requirements that Mrs Simpson made for the renter of the apartment?}

node.surface: Susie thinks this sort of responsibility might put people off.

node.category: Q3.5.1: {What impression does Mrs Simpsons room make?}

node.surface: Like the factory, Mrs Simpson's room tries hard to be dust-free and clean,

node.category: Q3.5.2: {Is the room as clean as Mrs Simpsons wants it to be?}

node.surface: but it smells of urine.

node.category: Q3.5.3: {Why does Mrs Simpsons room smell of urine?}

node.surface: Susie suspects Mrs Simpson wets the bed and doesn't know.

node.category: Q2.1.1: {What about Susies work?}

node.surface: Susie can go a whole twelve-hour shift without the bathroom.

node.category: Q2.1.2: {Can her coworkers to it too?}

node.surface: Some of the others use plastic bottles under the conveyor belt and inside their suits.

node.category: Q2.1.3: {Why don't they simply use the restrooms?}

node.surface: The company allows for five-minute breaks every three hours,

node.category: Q2.1.4: {Wouldn't this be enough time to use the restrooms?}

node.surface: but it takes longer than that just to come back through decontamination.

node.category: Q1.8.1: {What does Susie do now?}

node.surface: Susie hangs her towel on the radiator, curling her fingers around the warm bars.

node.category: Q1.8.2.1: {What does she see as she does this?}

node.surface: Along the shelves are glass jars of coloured salts,
and powders,
and liquids.

node.category: Q1.8.2.2: {What does she do with these containers?}

node.surface: She opens a jar and inhales.

node.category: Q1.8.3: {What does she smell?}
Q1.8.4: {What does this smell remind her of?}

node.surface: She remembers her mother's long dark hair, the thin stripes of grey.

node.category: Q1.8.5: {What happens now?}

node.surface: The flat crystals dissolve into oil that disappears in her dry palms.

node.category: Q1.8.2.3.1: {What does Susie do Now as she opened the jar?}

node.surface: She sprinkles some into the water.

node.category: Q1.8.2.3.2 : {How many does she sprinkle into the water?}

node.surface: Not as many as she would like, but some.

node.category: Q1.9.1: {What does Susie do now, as she sprinkled some crystals into the water?}

node.surface: She presses her nose to the clean towels stacked on the shelf.

node.category: Q1.9.2: {What to the clean towels stacked on the shelf smell like?}

node.surface: Washing powder and sunshine.

node.category: Q1.9.3: {And how do her own towels smell in comparision?}

node.surface: Her own towel smells of old socks and the unwashed skin scent that leaks under the door of the taxi driver's room.

node.category: Q1.10.1: {What does Susie do now, after she smelled the clean towels?}
She waves her hands through the steam of the running tap.
Q1.10.2: {What does Susie think about, as she waves her hands through the steam of the running tap?}

node.surface: In the factory, the conveyor belts move with constant speed, greased silent.

node.category: Q1.10.3: {What effect has the fact that the conveyor belts move with constant speed on Susie?}

node.surface: If she's thinking of something else, like the seamless way her mother poured tea or her father's whiskers above her mother's delicate cups, she will think the belt has stopped.
She will think the microchips are standing still

node.category: Q1.10.4: {Doesn't she hear anything else?}

node.surface: and the only sound is her circling, oily breath.

node.category: Q1.10.5: {What will eventually disturb the silence?}

node.surface: Then she'll hear the sticky of a defect from further along the belt and she'll remember where she is.

node.category: Q1.11.1: {What does Susie do now, after she her hands through the running tap?}

node.surface: She slips into the water.

node.category: Q1.11.2: {What does she do directly after she slips into the water?}

node.surface: She inhales.

node.category: Q1.11.3: {What does Susie think about as she inhales?}

node.surface: She prepares for the lavender memory of her mother's cheek against her forehead.

node.category: Q1.11.4: {Does that memory of her mother actually come up?}

node.surface: But all she smells is chlorine and the wet-dogness of her towel.

node.category: Q1.11.5: {Does Susie mind the bad smell?}

node.surface: Still, she resolves to enjoy it.

node.category: Q1.11.6: {What about the water inside the bathtub?}

node.surface: The water slinks past her skin, touches her lips.

node.category: Q1.11.7: {What does Susie do to her wet lips?}

node.surface: She licks them dry.

node.category: Q1.11.8: {What is she thinking about while she is licking her lips dry?}

node.surface: She imagines her mother's perfectly brewed tea.

node.category: Q1.11.9: {What does Susie do now}

node.surface: She takes a deep breath.

node.category: Q1.11.10: {What is Susie going to do after she took the bath?}

node.surface: After, she will change Mrs Simpson's sheets, and hopefully, Mrs Simpson will never know.
